bug.author: nthmost
bug.summary: st.markdown: unsafe_allow_html keyword fails to apply below first line in multiline string.
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h1>Summary</denchmark-h>
Attempting to style some text using explicit HTML and the unsafe_allow_html keyword with st.markdown(), all lines printed after the first line are printing HTML tags as-is instead of being allowed to style the text. <denchmark-h:h1>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-code>import streamlit as st
st.markdown(f"""## For official use only
<font size=16>symbol</font> code """, unsafe_allow_html=True) </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior:</denchmark-h>
I would expect that the font tags would apply their style to the word "symbol". <denchmark-h:h2>Actual behavior:</denchmark-h>
Font tags are printed to the screen as plain text. See screenshot. <denchmark-h:h2>Is this a regression?</denchmark-h>
no <denchmark-h:h1>Debug info</denchmark-h>
Streamlit version: 0.51.0 Python version: 3.7.5 Using Pipenv OS version: Mac OSX Catalina Browser version: any

comments.comment: Useful fact: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/rexxars/react-markdown/issues/40>react-markdown sets escapeHtml=true by default.</denchmark-link>
Update: I took a crack at this last week and wasn't able to figure out a solution that wouldn't involve replacing our markdown processor or forking react-markdown so it doesn't have this bug.

The indentation before the font tag was triggering a code block. See fix below. <denchmark-code>st.markdown(f"""## For official use only
<font size=16>symbol</font> code """, unsafe_allow_html=True) </denchmark-code>
